cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: To pass a slower-moving vehicle on a two-lane, two-way road, you must:
questions.answerA: Not cross the centerline.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Use the lane that belongs to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: Passing on a two-lane, two-way road requires good judgment because you must use the lane belonging to oncoming traffic to complete your pass. Only pass if you may safely and legally do so.

questions.question: Which of the following about winter driving is not true?
questions.answerA: Winter is the most difficult driving season.
questions.answerB: Checking your vehicle's antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels is especially important during the winter.
questions.answerC: Using cruise control in winter weather is a safe thing to do.
questions.answerD: It is best to use snow tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should not use cruise control on snow, in rain, in fog, or under similar hazardous conditions. Winter is the most difficult driving season and requires extra caution from drivers. It is important to consistently check your antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels. Using snow tires can increase a vehicle's traction on the surface of slippery roads.

questions.question: You may turn left on a red light if:
questions.answerA: There is no traffic coming from the opposite direction.
questions.answerB: You are turning from a two-way street onto a one-way street.
questions.answerC: You are turning from a one-way street onto another one-way street.
questions.answerD: The car in front of you turns left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left after stopping at a red light if you are in the left lane of a one-way street and are turning onto another one-way street, unless a posted sign prohibits it. You must first stop and yield to pedestrians and other traffic.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should adjust, if needed, when you get into a car to drive?
questions.answerA: Your seat belt
questions.answerC: Your rearview mirror
questions.answerD: Your seat
questions.explanation: When preparing to drive, you should first adjust your seat to ensure that you are in a comfortable position and can see the road clearly. Adjust your mirrors and steering wheel to be effective when your seat is fully adjusted.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: When driving on wet pavement, it's important to remember:
questions.answerA: That pavement is especially slippery right after it starts to rain.
questions.answerB: That wet roads can cause hydroplaning.
questions.answerC: To give yourself additional space when coming to a stop.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wet roadway surfaces can be dangerously slick, especially immediately following a rainfall. When you are driving on wet roads, your vehicle is traveling on a thin layer of oil, dirt, and water. Slow down when there is heavy rain, standing water, or slush on the road to reduce the risk of your wheels losing traction on the slick surface.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.answerD: All of these.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield for trains.
questions.answerD: Stop.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a railroad crossing on the road ahead. You should always slow down when approaching a railroad crossing. Trains cannot yield to cars, so you must let them pass before crossing the tracks.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerA: Entrance to full parking lots.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: If a person under 21 years of age consumes alcohol but is not driving a motor vehicle, the penalty for a first offense is:
questions.answerA: A 90-day driver license suspension and up to a $500 fine.
questions.answerC: A sentence to a corrections institution.
questions.answerD: Points on their driving record.
questions.explanation: The minimum penalties for a first underage drinking offense are a fine of up to $500, plus court costs, and a 90-day suspension.

questions.question: For an average person, how many minutes does the body need to process the alcohol in one drink?
questions.explanation: It takes a person of average weight at least one hour to process the alcohol in a single drink.

questions.question: If you are under age 21 and are convicted of carrying a false ID card, you will be required to pay a $500 fine and your license will be suspended for 90 days:
questions.answerA: Only if your blood alcohol content (BAC) is 0.02 percent or higher.
questions.answerB: Even if you were not driving.
questions.answerC: Only if you were driving at the time of arrest.
questions.answerD: Only if your blood alcohol content (BAC) is 0.02 percent or higher and you were driving at the time of arrest.
questions.explanation: Even if you are not driving, your driving privilege will be suspended if you are under 21 years of age and are convicted of possessing alcohol, lying about your age to obtain alcohol, or carrying a false ID card. The minimum penalties include a fine of $500, plus court costs, and a 90-day license suspension for the first offense.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.

questions.question: From the center lane, which maneuver(s) can you perform?
questions.answerA: You may make left turns.
questions.answerC: You may pass slow-moving traffic.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates where a lane is reserved for the exclusive use of left-turning vehicles from either direction. Such a lane may not be used for passing or for through-traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.answerD: No turning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited. Do not make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: What can you do to avoid the need to make emergency stops while driving in traffic?
questions.answerA: Honk your horn to make others aware of your presence.
questions.answerB: Look ahead and maintain a safe following distance.
questions.answerC: Drive in the right lane only.
questions.answerD: Drive more slowly than the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Keeping a safe following distance will enable you to react to an upcoming problem without the need for a emergency stop, which could cause a driver behind you to crash into the back of your vehicle.

questions.question: A bicyclist who doesn’t obey traffic laws:
questions.answerA: Is in the right because bicyclists don’t have to obey traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Will always receive a warning from law enforcement.
questions.answerD: Will have their bicycle impounded.
questions.explanation: All bicyclists have the same rights, duties, and responsibilities as drivers of motor vehicles. Motorists and bicyclists who do not obey traffic laws can be ticketed.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: An orange triangle on the back of a vehicle indicates that the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Carries radioactive materials.
questions.answerC: Travels at slower speeds than normal traffic.
questions.answerD: Makes frequent stops.
questions.explanation: In rural areas, an orange triangle is displayed on the back of farm tractors and horse-drawn vehicles designed to operate at speeds of 25 mph or less.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerA: The effect that alcohol has.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: When faced with an oncoming car to the left and a bicyclist to the right, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Let the car pass and then pass the bike.
questions.answerD: Pass the bike quickly.
questions.explanation: When there is more than one potential hazard on the road, you should ensure that you only have to deal with one of them at a time. For example, when there is a bicyclist on the right that you want to pass and an oncoming car to the left, you should not try to squeeze between both at the same time. Instead, let the oncoming car pass, and then pass the bicyclist.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Have to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.answerD: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: Before changing lanes on a multilane highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should look in your rearview and side mirrors to make sure no one is trying to pass you. You should also look over your shoulder to make sure that no one is in your blind spot.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the steering wheel to move freely.
questions.answerB: Let the car slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach a garage.
questions.answerD: Brake hard to stop the car immediately.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires blows out, you should hold the steering wheel tightly, stay off of the brakes, slowly take your foot off of the gas pedal, and steer smoothly in the direction you want to go. Get to a safe spot where you can pull over to change the tire and let your vehicle slow to a stop.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.answerD: Green, yellow, red.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: After an emergency vehicle passes you with its siren on, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive closely behind the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive as quickly as the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerC: Avoid driving closer than 500 feet behind the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerD: Drive very slowly near the curb.
questions.explanation: When you resume driving again after being passed by an emergency vehicle, you must remain at least 500 feet behind it.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.answerD: Do not enter.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: A solid white line on the right edge of the highway slants in to the left. That shows that:
questions.answerA: There is an intersection just ahead.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a construction area.
questions.answerC: You will be required to turn left just ahead.
questions.answerD: The road will get narrower.
questions.explanation: A solid line along the side of the road indicates where its edge is, marking the boundary between the travel lane and the shoulder. If the edge line angles toward the center of the road, this means that the road is narrower ahead.

questions.question: Your brake lights tell other drivers that you:
questions.answerA: Are making a turn.
questions.answerC: Are changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Are slowing down or stopping.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's brake lights indicate to other drivers that you are slowing down or stopping. Your brake lights should always be in working order when you are driving on any roadway.

questions.question: Allowing a space cushion between your vehicle and its surroundings is important because it:
questions.answerA: Prevents distractions from other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Allows you time to react to unexpected situations.
questions.answerC: Keeps traffic flowing at a safe pace.
questions.answerD: Keeps other drivers alert.
questions.explanation: The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate:
questions.answerA: Stop on the shoulder of the road if you are tired.
questions.answerB: You should always use cruise control.
questions.answerC: Signal, check mirrors, and check blind spots before changing lanes.
questions.answerD: You should change lanes often.
questions.explanation: Signal, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot before changing lanes or passing on an interstate. Only stop on the shoulder of the interstate in the case of an emergency and change lanes as infrequently as possible. Cruise control should not be used in heavy traffic or under poor weather conditions.

questions.question: If you are arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol and you refuse to take the blood test, you will receive a:
questions.answerA: Drug counseling treatment.
questions.answerB: Sentence of one day in jail.
questions.answerC: Driver license suspension.
questions.answerD: $300 fine.
questions.explanation: If the police arrest you for driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs and you refuse to take one or more chemical tests of breath, blood, or urine, your driving privilege will be automatically suspended for one year.

questions.question: Drivers who eat and drink while driving:
questions.answerA: Make no driving errors.
questions.answerC: Are better drivers because they are not hungry.
questions.answerD: Have trouble controlling their vehicles.
questions.explanation: Choosing to eat, drink, or smoke while driving is dangerous because these actions require a driver to remove their hands from the wheel and their eyes from the road. Drivers who engage in distracting activities while driving have trouble staying in their lanes and controlling their vehicles.

questions.question: When driving on wet roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your following distance to five or six seconds.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance to two seconds.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your following distance.
questions.answerD: Maintain the four-second following distance rule.
questions.explanation: When roads become wet, you should increase your following distance to five or six seconds.

questions.question: When driving through a work zone, it is a good safety practice to:
questions.answerA: Drive closely to the vehicle in front of you to keep traffic flowing freely.
questions.answerB: Shorten your usual following distance by about one-half.
questions.answerC: Turn on your cruise control.
questions.answerD: Double your usual following distance.
questions.explanation: The most common type of crash in work zones is the rear-end collision. To avoid this hazard, it is recommended that you double your following distance as you approach a work zone.

questions.question: You should honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling through an intersection.
questions.answerC: See a child who is about to run into the street.
questions.answerD: Are parallel parking.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used as a warning in situations where you think another driver or a pedestrian does not see you. For example, if a child begins to run into the street in front of your vehicle, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit in this state is ____ miles per hour .
questions.explanation: The maximum speed limit in Pennsylvania is 70 mph.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerA: Upcoming intersections.
questions.answerC: An upcoming curve in the road.
questions.answerD: Changes in traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right.

questions.question: Defensive driving is:
questions.answerA: Identifying dangerous driving situations and taking action to avoid accidents.
questions.answerB: Defending yourself against poor drivers by getting ahead of them in traffic.
questions.answerC: Following the vehicle ahead of you at a close distance.
questions.answerD: Quickly changing lanes and shifting in and out of traffic congestion.
questions.explanation: You drive defensively when you identify dangerous driving situations and take action before an accident occurs. Defensive driving helps prevent conflicts with aggressive, offensive, discourteous, careless, inattentive, impulsive, ignorant, or intoxicated drivers or pedestrians.

questions.question: Traffic fatalities in work zones are most commonly the result of:
questions.answerA: Tire blowouts.
questions.answerB: Hydroplaning due to water sprayed on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Loss of steering control after driving over wet paint.
questions.answerD: Carelessness and speeding.
questions.explanation: Carelessness and speeding are the main causes of traffic-related fatalities in work zones.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.answerD: Added lane.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: At an intersection with a stop sign, you should stop and:
questions.answerA: Check your rearview mirror for cars tailgating.
questions.answerB: Move when the vehicle ahead of you moves.
questions.answerC: Look right first, then left, then right again.
questions.answerD: Look left first, then right, then left again.
questions.explanation: When stopped at an intersection, you should first look to your left, as vehicles coming from the left are closer to you than vehicles coming from the right. Look to your right, then look to your left again, in case there are any vehicles coming from that direction that you did not see at first glance.

questions.question: When passing a bicyclist, you should:
questions.answerA: Blast your horn to alert the bicyclist.
questions.answerB: Give them at least four feet of space.
questions.answerC: Remain on the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Put on your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: The law requires you to allow at least four feet of space between your vehicle and a bicyclist when passing them.

questions.question: Your blind spot is the area of the road:
questions.answerA: You cannot see without moving your head.
questions.answerC: You see in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: You see in your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see without moving their head. They can be located to the sides of and behind a vehicle.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: On a two-lane road, you may pass another vehicle on the right:
questions.answerA: When driving on a single lane entrance ramp.
questions.answerB: When the driver you are passing is traveling more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: When the driver you are passing is making a left turn.
questions.explanation: You may pass on the right when the driver ahead of you is making or signaling a left turn, provided that you stay on the berm or shoulder. You may also pass on the right when you are on a roadway with two or more marked traffic lanes in each direction.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get some coffee.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.answerD: Turn on the radio.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Right turn.
questions.answerC: Lane change.
questions.answerD: Road curve.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a T intersection is ahead.

questions.question: The right edge of a road is marked by a ____ line.
questions.answerA: Broken white
questions.answerC: Solid white
questions.answerD: Broken yellow
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to mark the right edge of a road.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: Before turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your signal.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.answerD: Change lanes.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should activate your turn signal three to four seconds before your turn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: Minimum speed limit.
questions.answerD: No parking.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. Wherever this regulation sign is posted, U-turns are not permitted.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerA: Either side
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.answerD: The left side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: If you see this sign above your lane, you:
questions.answerA: May not exit the freeway.
questions.answerB: May either continue through the interchange or exit the freeway from your current lane.
questions.answerC: May stay in your lane and continue through the interchange.
questions.answerD: Must exit the freeway, if you stay in your current lane.
questions.explanation: If a yellow panel with the message "Exit only" is on a highway sign, the lane below the sign will not continue through the interchange. Instead, the lane will go off of the roadway to form a ramp. If you are in a lane directly under an "Exit only" sign, you may change lanes to move through the interchange or you must exit the highway.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: On two-lane, two-way streets or highways, you should start left turns:
questions.answerA: Close to the centerline.
questions.answerC: In the right lane.
questions.answerD: From any lane.
questions.explanation: On two-lane, two-way streets or highways, you should make left turns from as close to the centerline as possible.

questions.question: To drive safely at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerB: Not drive if you are tired.
questions.answerC: Make sure your headlights are working properly.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: At night, visibility is reduced. Take steps to make driving in the dark more safe for you and the other drivers on the road.

questions.question: If you are unable to get a good view of cross traffic when stopped at an intersection controlled by a stop sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait five seconds, then proceed.
questions.answerC: Put down your windows, listen for traffic, and then proceed.
questions.answerD: Pull forward slowly, check for traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when clear.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a stop sign where you cannot see cross traffic, yield to any pedestrians and then carefully pull forward past the stop line until you can see clearly. Check for traffic and pedestrians. Go ahead when the intersection is clear.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerA: Increases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: When you park on the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Keep your turn signal on.
questions.answerD: Turn your lights on.
questions.explanation: If you must park on the roadway, use your four-way flashers and allow enough space for passing vehicles. Make sure your vehicle can be seen for at least 500 feet in both directions.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerC: Red
questions.answerD: Black
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to separate lanes traveling in the same direction (as well as to mark the right edge of the road). Broken white lines separate lanes traveling in the same direction and may be crossed to pass. Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: You need to use extra caution when driving near a pedestrian using a white cane because:
questions.answerA: He or she is deaf.
questions.answerB: He or she is a police officer.
questions.answerC: He or she is blind.
questions.answerD: He or she has poor balance.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: It is best to keep a space cushion:
questions.answerA: Only in back of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the left and right sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only in front of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: On all sides of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you will have time to react to hazards on the roadway, it is best to keep a cushion of space on all sides of your vehicle. Do not crowd vehicles to your left and right sides.

questions.question: This green arrow on a lane use control signal means:
questions.answerA: You may use this lane.
questions.answerB: No traffic is allowed in this lane.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: You must merge into this lane.
questions.explanation: A steady downward green arrow over a traffic lane means you may use the lane indicated.

questions.question: You are driving in the right lane of a multilane highway and want to move into the left lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Look in your rearview mirror for traffic behind you before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Look over your left shoulder for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Look in your side mirror for traffic and turn on your directional signal.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should always verify that there are no other vehicles in the lane you want to enter by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. You should signal every time you change lanes.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerA: Are usually not important.
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians ahead.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.answerD: Flagger ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear your seat belt.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: If a traffic light at an intersection is broken or not functioning, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for it to be repaired.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait for a police officer to arrive.
questions.answerC: Continue as if the intersection is a four-way stop.
questions.answerD: Continue as you normally would.
questions.explanation: An intersection with a non-functioning traffic signal should be treated as a four-way stop.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.answerD: When making turns.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Intersection.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.answerD: Lane change.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that an intersection with a crossing road is ahead.

questions.question: When making a turn, you must ____ your speed.
questions.answerA: Increase
questions.answerC: Vary
questions.answerD: Reduce
questions.explanation: When turning, you should reduce to a speed that allows you to maintain control of your vehicle, stay in your lane, and react to unexpected situations.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerA: Communicate with other road users.
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.answerD: Avoid driving during rush hour.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: The most important thing to remember about speed management and curves is that you must:
questions.answerA: Drive at the posted speed limit as you enter the curve, then slow down at the sharpest part of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down before you enter the curve.
questions.answerC: Accelerate gently before you enter the curve.
questions.answerD: Drive at the posted speed limit before, throughout, and after the curve.
questions.explanation: The most important thing to remember about driving in curves is that your vehicle’s inertia may make it difficult to turn. To maintain control, it is essential that you slow down before entering the curve.

questions.question: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot when:
questions.answerA: Pulling toward or away from a curb.
questions.answerC: Changing lanes.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot every time you want to change your vehicle's position. If you are turning, changing lanes, or pulling toward or away from a curb, you should check your blind spots.

questions.question: It is against the law for anyone under the age of 21 to ____ alcohol.
questions.answerA: Serve
questions.answerC: Be in the presence of
questions.answerD: Transport
questions.explanation: It is illegal in Pennsylvania for anyone under the age of 21 to buy or consume alcohol, have it in their possession, or have it in a vehicle that they are driving. Even if you are not driving, your driving privileges can be suspended if you are convicted of one of several alcohol-related offenses, including transporting alcohol.

questions.question: If your turn signals fail, you should use ____ to indicate that you are turning.
questions.answerA: Your horn
questions.answerC: Hand signals
questions.answerD: Your emergency flashers
questions.explanation: If your vehicle's turn signals do not work, you should use hand signals to indicate when you intend to change direction.

questions.question: While driving on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you encounter a bicyclist traveling in the same direction. What is the safest way to pass the bicyclist?
questions.answerA: Slow down and wait until there is no traffic approaching, then pass the bicyclist while leaving him or her sufficient space.
questions.answerB: Continue driving straight. It is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
questions.answerC: Do not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
questions.answerD: Honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.
questions.explanation: You should pass a bicyclist the same way you would pass any other vehicle, but not so fast or close to them that you throw debris in their face or blow them around with the draft of air from your vehicle. Allow at least 3 feet of space between your side mirror and the bicyclist, or at least 5 feet on higher speed roads or when there is a group of bicyclists. Honking unnecessarily may startle riders and make them more likely to crash.

questions.question: If an oncoming driver is heading toward you in your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn, steer right, and accelerate.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn, steer left, and brake.
questions.answerC: Blow your horn, steer right, and brake.
questions.answerD: Stay in the center of your lane, blow your horn, and brake.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle is approaching you head-on in your lane, you should first honk your horn to attract attention. If the other driver does not move over, try to escape to the right. If you swerve left and the other driver corrects at the last instant, you will still crash. If a collision is unavoidable, brake firmly and steadily. Every mile per hour you slow down will reduce the impact.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp right turn.
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right, then sharply left.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead turns sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: Who must yield when a driver is turning and a pedestrian is crossing without a traffic light?
questions.answerA: Whoever started moving last
questions.answerC: Whoever is slower
questions.answerD: The pedestrian
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians when they are crossing at any intersection without a traffic light, whether or not there is a crosswalk.

questions.question: When you are in a line of traffic that is crossing a railroad track that has no signals or gates:
questions.answerA: You have the right-of-way and do not need to check for trains.
questions.answerB: You may pass slower drivers while crossing the track.
questions.answerC: You need to make sure there is space for your vehicle to get all the way across the tracks without stopping.
questions.answerD: All of the above
questions.explanation: If you are following another vehicle at a railroad crossing, check to make sure you have enough room to get all the way across before you drive onto the tracks. You should never try to pass another vehicle as you approach or cross a railroad crossing. Always check for trains before crossing any railroad tracks.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerA: Do not affect driving abilities.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.answerD: Are not distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: When is it illegal to drive below the speed limit?
questions.answerA: When driving slowly disrupts the normal flow of traffic
questions.answerB: When in heavy traffic in a construction zone
questions.answerC: Only when driving in rural areas.
questions.answerD: When driving under adverse weather conditions
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive so slowly that you disrupt the normal flow of traffic. You may receive a citation for driving too slowly.

questions.question: Parental consent to conduct breath, blood, and urine tests is:
questions.answerA: Not required.
questions.answerC: Required for people under 16-years-old.
questions.answerD: Required from both parents.
questions.explanation: If you are underage and are arrested and detained for blood, breath and/or urine testing, parental consent to conduct these tests is not required; however, the police will notify your parents of the arrest.

questions.question: The risk of hydroplaning can can be reduced by driving:
questions.answerA: Through shallow water.
questions.answerC: More slowly.
questions.answerD: Through deep water.
questions.explanation: Because hydroplaning is caused by driving too quickly in wet conditions, the risk of it happening can be reduced by driving more slowly.

questions.question: When approaching a stopped school bus with its red lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop five feet away from the bus.
questions.answerB: Stop only if you see children are present.
questions.answerC: Stop and remain stopped until it appears safe to proceed.
questions.answerD: Stop and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm has been withdrawn.
questions.explanation: When a school bus stops with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must stop at least 10 feet away from the bus. Remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing, the stop arm has been withdrawn, and the children have reached a safe place. This is the law whether you are approaching the bus from behind, approaching it from the opposite direction, or approaching it at an intersection at which the school bus is stopped.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerD: Block the passing lane.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or using a guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerC: Proceed normally.
questions.answerD: Drive away quickly.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: If a police officer requires you to take a blood, breath, or urine test, you:
questions.answerA: May choose which test you prefer.
questions.answerC: May refuse if underage.
questions.answerD: Must take the test or your license will be suspended.
questions.explanation: If the police arrest you for driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs and you refuse to take one or more chemical tests of breath, blood, or urine, your driving privilege will be automatically suspended for one year. This suspension will remain in place even if you are found not guilty of driving under the influence.

questions.question: The posted speed limit shows:
questions.answerA: Only a recommended driving speed.
questions.answerB: The exact speed at which you must travel to avoid a ticket.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe driving speed under ideal road and weather conditions.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe driving speed under all road conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit sign shows the maximum legal driving speed for the stretch of highway where it is posted. Driving safely may require you to travel more slowly than the posted limit. When conditions are less than ideal, drivers should slow down.

questions.question: “Highway hypnosis” is a driving condition that can result from:
questions.answerA: Staring at the roadway for long periods of time.
questions.answerC: Too much sleep the night before your trip.
questions.answerD: Short trips on expressways.
questions.explanation: "Highway hypnosis” happens when you stare straight ahead at the roadway for long periods of time and stop actively scanning ahead, behind, and around your vehicle. This can lead you to zone out, making you very likely to crash into traffic slowing or stopping ahead of you.

questions.question: The top type of vehicular crash involving 16-year-old drivers in Pennsylvania is:
questions.answerA: Single vehicle/run-off-the-road.
questions.answerC: Driving in reverse on a side street.
questions.answerD: Driving on the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: The most frequent crash type in which 16-year-old drivers in Pennsylvania are involved is a single-vehicle, run-off-the-road crash. From 2009 to 2011, there were 2,293 crashes and 45 people killed.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Unbuckle your seat belt and lower your window.
questions.answerB: Get your paperwork ready before the officer reaches your car.
questions.answerC: Stay in your vehicle with your hands on the steering wheel and wait for the officer to approach you.
questions.answerD: Get out of your car and walk toward the patrol car.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by the police, keep your hands on the wheel and ask any passengers to keep their hands in view as well. You should remain in the vehicle unless the police officer asks you to get out. Wait until the officer asks you to retrieve your driver license, registration, and insurance cards.

questions.question: The minimum drinking age in this state is age:
questions.explanation: The legal drinking age in Pennsylvania is 21.

questions.question: While driving, you come upon a sign displaying the words “Reduced speed, 35 mph." This means:
questions.answerA: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at this sign.
questions.answerB: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at the next speed limit sign.
questions.answerC: That you have plenty of time to slow down before the reduced speed zone.
questions.answerD: That you should reduce your speed to 35 mph, but only under poor weather conditions.
questions.explanation: "Reduced speed" signs inform drivers that they must reduce their speeds. If a new speed limit is posted on one of these signs, the new speed limit begins at the sign.

questions.question: On a two-lane street, your vehicle is being followed by a fire engine that is not using its emergency signals. You should:
questions.answerA: Continue to drive in a normal manner.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of its way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, move as far to the right as possible, and stop.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by an emergency vehicle that is not using its siren or flashing lights, you do not need to clear a path. Continue driving in a normal manner.

questions.question: If under 21 years of age, you are considered to be driving while under the influence if your blood alcohol level is:
questions.answerA: 0.08 percent or higher.
questions.answerC: 0.05 percent or higher.
questions.answerD: 0.02 percent or higher.
questions.explanation: If you are under age 21, Pennsylvania's laws do not permit you to drive with any measurable alcohol in your system. If you are under 21, you are considered to be driving under the influence if your blood alcohol level is 0.02 percent or greater.

questions.question: Highway and expressway guide signs are:
questions.answerA: Orange with black letters.
questions.answerC: Yellow with black letters.
questions.answerD: Red with white letters.
questions.explanation: Highway and expressway guide signs are green with white letters.

questions.question: Pennant-shaped signs indicate:
questions.answerA: School zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.answerD: Railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs usually indicate no passing zones. Text will also be on the sign to confirm that it is a no passing zone.

questions.question: You do not have to stop for a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm extended if you:
questions.answerA: Are driving on the opposite side of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: See no children present.
questions.answerD: Can safely pass on the left.
questions.explanation: The only situation during which you are not required to stop for a school bus that is stopped with its lights flashing and stop arm extended is if you are driving on the opposite side of a divided highway.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.answerD: Easier on your eyes.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle if the line dividing your lane from the lane you wish to enter is a ____ line.
questions.answerA: Broken white
questions.answerC: Solid yellow
questions.answerD: Solid white
questions.explanation: White lines separate traffic lanes traveling in the same direction. You may cross broken white lines to pass, as long as the passing lane is clear.

questions.question: It is against the law for anyone under the age of 21 to ____ alcohol.
questions.answerA: Wear clothing advertising
questions.answerC: Consume
questions.answerD: Serve
questions.explanation: It is against the law for anyone under 21 to buy or consume alcohol, have it in their possession, or have it in a vehicle that they are driving.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means that you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with care.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed when a green light appears.
questions.answerD: Stop and proceed when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means "caution." If you approach such a light, slow down, look, and proceed with care.

questions.question: Drivers entering a roundabout or traffic circle:
questions.answerA: Must always stop before entering.
questions.answerB: Must yield to drivers already in the roundabout or traffic circle.
questions.answerC: Have the right-of-way if there is one lane.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way if there are two lanes.
questions.explanation: Drivers entering a roundabout or traffic circle must yield the right-of-way to drivers already in the circle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: T intersection.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.answerD: Do not block intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a T intersection and should prepare to turn either right or left.

questions.question: Stress can affect your driving by:
questions.answerA: Lowing your ability to focus on driving.
questions.answerB: Decreasing your chances of an accident.
questions.answerC: Causing you to fall asleep at the wheel.
questions.answerD: Making you more aware of others around you.
questions.explanation: Emotions can have a great effect on your driving ability. You may not be able to drive well if you are overly worried, excited, afraid, angry, or sad. Stress can lessen your concentration on the task of driving. It is better to wait to drive than to risk driving while you are emotionally unstable.

questions.question: The law gives ____ the right-of-way at intersections.
questions.answerA: No one
questions.answerC: Drivers going straight
questions.answerD: Drivers turning right
questions.explanation: The law does not give anyone the right-of-way at intersections; it only says who must yield. Even when one driver is legally required to yield the right-of-way, if they fail to do so, other drivers are still required to stop or yield as necessary to avoid a crash.

questions.question: When entering a street from a driveway, you:
questions.answerA: Must drive slowly to allow approaching vehicles and pedestrians time to get out of your way.
questions.answerB: Must honk your horn so approaching vehicles and pedestrians know to give you room.
questions.answerC: Must stop and proceed only when there are no pedestrians or vehicles approaching.
questions.answerD: Can disregard any pedestrians if there is no sidewalk.
questions.explanation: Always stop before entering the roadway from a driveway and yield to any approaching vehicles or crossing pedestrians. The stop should be made before crossing the sidewalk area. Failure to stop is unlawful.

questions.question: Before turning left, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerC: Swing to the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until oncoming traffic has a red light.
questions.explanation: When turning left at a traffic signal, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is usually caused by:
questions.answerA: Excessive stops.
questions.answerC: Sudden turns.
questions.answerD: Excessive speed.
questions.explanation: Your tires become less effective at clearing water from the road as you increase your speed. If you drive too fast, they may lose their grip entirely, leaving the vehicle sliding on a film of water. This is known as "hydroplaning."

questions.question: A single broken yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: The speed limit is ____ miles per hour when yellow lights are flashing on a school zone speed limit sign.
questions.explanation: When the flashing yellow lights on a school zone sign are activated, or during an indicated school zone time period, you may travel no faster than 15 mph.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: When driving in fog:
questions.answerA: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Use your high beams.
questions.answerD: It makes no difference which lights you use.
questions.explanation: You should use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.answerD: Speed up to pass.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: You must use your headlights when other vehicles are not visible from ____ feet away.
questions.explanation: State law requires you to use your headlights any time you cannot see pedestrians or other vehicles on the highway for a distance of 1,000 feet ahead of your vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving on a highway divided by two solid yellow lines. You may:
questions.answerA: Cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.
questions.answerB: Cross these lines to pass other vehicles, but only if there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Cross these lines under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: Cross these lines only to make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are used to mark roadways where passing is prohibited from both directions. You may cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.

questions.question: If you are driving near a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Allow the motorcycle to use a complete lane.
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder beside the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Allow the motorcycle to use only half of a lane.
questions.answerD: Pass using the same lane as the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle is a full-size vehicle with the same privileges as any other vehicle on the roadway. You should allow a motorcyclist a full lane width. Although it may seem as though there is enough room in the traffic lane for a larger vehicle and a motorcycle, remember that the motorcycle needs room to maneuver safely.

questions.question: If you want to get off the freeway but you have missed your exit, you should:
questions.answerA: Go to the next exit.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn through the median.
questions.answerC: Pull onto the shoulder and back your car to the exit.
questions.answerD: Flag down a police officer for an escort back to your exit.
questions.explanation: If you miss your exit, you should take the next exit. Do not stop or back up on the highway, swerve across multiple lanes to try to make the exit at the last second, or cross over the median to turn around. All of these maneuvers are illegal and extremely dangerous.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: When the train has passed.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: Roads freeze quickly when they are:
questions.answerA: Flat.
questions.answerC: In the sun.
questions.answerD: Shaded.
questions.explanation: In cold or wet weather, you should take special care on sections of road that are shaded by trees or buildings. These areas freeze more quickly than the rest of the road and are the last parts of the road to dry.

questions.question: A yellow and black diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns you about conditions on or near the road.
questions.answerB: Helps direct you to cities and towns ahead.
questions.answerC: Tells you about traffic laws and regulations.
questions.answerD: Tells you about road construction ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs, which tell you about conditions on or near the road ahead, are usually diamond-shaped with black symbols or words on a yellow background.

questions.question: When traveling at highway speeds on a dry road, a safe following distance is at least:
questions.answerA: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Two car lengths.
questions.explanation: In general, when driving on a dry highway, a four-second following distance will provide adequate time to steer or brake to avoid a hazard.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerC: Black
questions.answerD: Yellow
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to divide traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.answerD: No right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits U-turns. Do not make a U-turn where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A single broken white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: After a train has passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Check again for approaching trains and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Immediately proceed across the tracks.
questions.answerD: Blow your horn and proceed.
questions.explanation: Even at a railroad crossing with only one track, you should not immediately start across after a train has passed. Always check for other approaching trains before proceeding.

questions.question: A flashing red light at a railroad crossing means:
questions.answerA: Stop. Do not proceed until signals are deactivated.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed if the tracks are clear.
questions.answerC: Proceed with caution.
questions.answerD: You have the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when a signal warns of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not move forward or attempt to go around any gate or ignore any signal of an approaching train.

questions.question: When you are planning to make a turn, you should activate your turn signals:
questions.answerA: Only if there are other drivers following you.
questions.answerB: Just as the front of your car reaches the intersection.
questions.answerC: Three to four seconds before you reach the intersection.
questions.answerD: Two car lengths before reaching the intersection.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should signal three to four seconds before turning.

questions.question: ____ limit your concentration, perception, judgment, and memory.
questions.answerA: Only a blood alcohol level greater than the legal limit can
questions.answerC: Even the smallest amount of alcohol can
questions.answerD: Only a blood alcohol level greater than 0.05 percent can
questions.explanation: Even the smallest amount of alcohol will reduce your concentration, perception, judgment and memory, and your driving skills will suffer. No one can drink and drive safely.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.answerD: Stop exactly where you are.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Cars behind you.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If there are no signals at a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop if you see or hear a train approaching.
questions.answerB: Proceed as quickly as possible over the tracks.
questions.answerC: Proceed through the crossing at a normal rate.
questions.answerD: Proceed slowly over the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are no signals at an upcoming railroad crossing, you should slow down and be prepared to stop if you see or hear a train approaching.

questions.question: When approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and/or flashing lights, a driver must immediately:
questions.answerA: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and slow down.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and turn on their vehicle's four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the emergency vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: When you are approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its lights, sirens, and/or other warning devices, you must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop.

questions.question: If the rear of your vehicle starts to skid left, you should:
questions.answerA: Steer left.
questions.answerC: Accelerate.
questions.answerD: Steer right.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle starts to skid on a wet or icy road, look and steer in the direction you want to go. If the rear of your vehicle is skidding to the left, turn the wheel to the left. If the rear of your vehicle is skidding to the right, turn the wheel to the right.

questions.question: When sharing the road with a truck, it is important to remember that trucks generally:
questions.answerA: Require longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerB: Require less time to pass on a downgrade than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerC: Require a smaller turning radius than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerD: Require less time to pass on an incline than smaller vehicles do.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, trucks need longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.

questions.question: The best way to deal with tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes to get the other driver to back off.
questions.answerC: Change lanes or gradually slow down to encourage them to pass.
questions.answerD: Ignore them.
questions.explanation: Check the traffic behind you several times a minute to know if another driver is tailgating, approaching too fast, or trying to pass. If another car is following you too closely, slow down and let it pass. Most rear-end collisions are caused by vehicles following too closely.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: Your ability to stop is affected by:
questions.answerA: Signal lights.
questions.answerC: The time of day.
questions.answerD: The condition of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to stop is greatly affected by the condition of the road. You need to reduce your speed when road conditions are poor in order to maintain control of your vehicle. You will be at risk if you are driving too quickly on roads that are slippery and you need to stop.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.answerD: May not turn right.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: At night, it is hardest to see:
questions.answerA: Road signs.
questions.answerC: Other motorists.
questions.answerD: Street lights.
questions.explanation: Compared to signs and other roadside objects, pedestrians are hardest to see at night.

questions.question: Night driving can be more difficult than driving during the day because:
questions.answerA: Cars overheat more quickly at night.
questions.answerB: Visibility is reduced in the dark.
questions.answerC: It is more likely to be raining at night.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to encounter a motorcycle at night.
questions.explanation: At night, your field of vision is reduced. To make sure you are able to react to hazards on the roadway, always use appropriate headlights. Drive slowly enough that you are able to stop within the distance that you can see ahead.

questions.question: You may continue carefully through an intersection with a yellow light if:
questions.answerA: There is an emergency vehicle crossing your lane.
questions.answerC: You are turning right.
questions.answerD: You are already within the intersection when the light changes to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a steady yellow light appears when you are already within an intersection, you should continue through the intersection carefully.

questions.question: Anything that requires you to ____ could cause you to crash.
questions.answerA: Take your eyes off the road
questions.answerB: Take your hands off the wheel
questions.answerC: Take your attention away from the task of driving
questions.answerD: All of the above
questions.explanation: Anything that causes you to take your attention away from driving, take your eyes off the road, and/or take your hands off the wheel is a distraction.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the speed at which you travel?
questions.answerA: The safest speed to drive depends on many conditions.
questions.answerC: The speed limit is always a safe speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerating is always dangerous.
questions.explanation: To determine a safe driving speed, you must take into account many factors, including road conditions, visibility, and the flow of other traffic. When conditions are less than perfect, safety may require you to drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal means that a ____ light will soon appear.
questions.answerA: Flashing yellow
questions.answerC: Steady red
questions.answerD: Flashing red
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light on a traffic signal indicates that a steady red light will soon appear.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
