questions.question: When making a right turn on a green light, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your normal driving speed.
questions.answerB: Stop and look for nearby police cars.
questions.answerC: Yield to pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Increase your normal driving speed.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right or left at a steady green light. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.answerD: Do not enter.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: You are coming to a railroad crossing where the crossing signals are flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for a train.
questions.answerB: Slow down and look for a train.
questions.answerC: Look for a train, then speed up.
questions.answerD: Do what the vehicle ahead of you does.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must stop your vehicle no closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail if an installed electric or mechanical signal is giving warning of an approaching train. Be aware of other warning signs that may indicate an oncoming train, including seeing a lowered crossing gate or hearing an oncoming train.

questions.question: An orange triangle on the back of a vehicle indicates that the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Carries radioactive materials.
questions.answerC: Travels at slower speeds than normal traffic.
questions.answerD: Makes frequent stops.
questions.explanation: In rural areas, an orange triangle is displayed on the back of farm tractors and horse-drawn vehicles designed to operate at speeds of 25 mph or less.

questions.question: Teenagers should try to get at least ____ of sleep each night to avoid the risk of crashing due to lack of sleep.
questions.answerA: Seven hours
questions.answerC: Eight hours
questions.answerD: Nine hours
questions.explanation: Teenagers who get less than eight hours of sleep per night are at an increased risk of crashing their vehicles when driving.

questions.question: If you are following a truck that swings left before making a right turn at an intersection, you should remember that it is very dangerous to:
questions.answerA: Try to squeeze between the truck and curb to make a right turn.
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes until the truck has completed the turn.
questions.answerC: Violate the four-second following distance rule.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn at the truck driver.
questions.explanation: Because large trucks must make wide turns, it may initially look like a truck is turning left when it is actually turning right. This makes it dangerous to try to pass a turning truck. Truck drivers cannot see vehicles that try to squeeze between them and the curb.

questions.question: If an oncoming driver is heading toward you in your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn, steer right, and accelerate.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn, steer left, and brake.
questions.answerC: Blow your horn, steer right, and brake.
questions.answerD: Stay in the center of your lane, blow your horn, and brake.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle is approaching you head-on in your lane, you should first honk your horn to attract attention. If the other driver does not move over, try to escape to the right. If you swerve left and the other driver corrects at the last instant, you will still crash. If a collision is unavoidable, brake firmly and steadily. Every mile per hour you slow down will reduce the impact.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Go.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerD: Stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: Before passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your headlights to alert the driver.
questions.answerB: Turn on your four-way flashers to warn the driver.
questions.answerC: Give the proper turn signal to show that you are changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to get the driver's attention.
questions.explanation: Before passing, make sure the passing lane is clear and activate the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes. Signal early enough for other drivers to know your plans in advance.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.answerD: Drive normally.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: The posted speed limit shows:
questions.answerA: Only a recommended driving speed.
questions.answerB: The exact speed at which you must travel to avoid a ticket.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe driving speed under ideal road and weather conditions.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe driving speed under all road conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit sign shows the maximum legal driving speed for the stretch of highway where it is posted. Driving safely may require you to travel more slowly than the posted limit. When conditions are less than ideal, drivers should slow down.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: It is against the law for anyone under the age of 21 to ____ alcohol.
questions.answerA: Wear clothing advertising
questions.answerC: Consume
questions.answerD: Serve
questions.explanation: It is against the law for anyone under 21 to buy or consume alcohol, have it in their possession, or have it in a vehicle that they are driving.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: Teenage drivers are more likely to be involved in a crash when:
questions.answerA: They are driving with their pet as a passenger.
questions.answerB: They are driving with adult passengers.
questions.answerC: They are driving with teenage passengers.
questions.answerD: They are driving without any passengers.
questions.explanation: Teenage drivers are more likely to have a crash when they are traveling with other teenagers as passengers than when they are driving alone or with adult passengers.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stopped with its stop arm extended, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and wait to proceed.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn before passing the bus on its left.
questions.answerC: Continue driving when they think most kids are probably done exiting the bus.
questions.answerD: Pass the bus before its door opens.
questions.explanation: When approaching a stopped school bus that is using its stop signal, a driver is required to come to a complete stop. They should not proceed until the stop arm is withdrawn.

questions.question: When you hear a fire engine siren behind you, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and stop.
questions.answerD: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren of an emergency vehicle, you must pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: At a four-way stop:
questions.answerA: The driver to arrive first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver to arrive last has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver should continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should wave the other drivers ahead.
questions.explanation: At four-way stops, traffic from all four directions must stop. The first vehicle to reach the intersection should move forward first. If two vehicles reach the intersection at the same time, the driver on the left yields to the driver on the right.

questions.question: If there are no signals at a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop if you see or hear a train approaching.
questions.answerB: Proceed as quickly as possible over the tracks.
questions.answerC: Proceed through the crossing at a normal rate.
questions.answerD: Proceed slowly over the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are no signals at an upcoming railroad crossing, you should slow down and be prepared to stop if you see or hear a train approaching.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The left lane is reserved for vehicles with a specific number of occupants.
questions.answerB: Specific turning movements are allowed from specific lanes.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.answerD: Drivers in both lanes are responsible for merging smoothly.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a high occupancy vehicle (HOV) lane. HOV lanes are reserved for use by buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers, as indicated on the sign.

questions.question: When approaching a stopped school bus with its red lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop five feet away from the bus.
questions.answerB: Stop only if you see children are present.
questions.answerC: Stop and remain stopped until it appears safe to proceed.
questions.answerD: Stop and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm has been withdrawn.
questions.explanation: When a school bus stops with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must stop at least 10 feet away from the bus. Remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing, the stop arm has been withdrawn, and the children have reached a safe place. This is the law whether you are approaching the bus from behind, approaching it from the opposite direction, or approaching it at an intersection at which the school bus is stopped.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns of existing or possible hazards.
questions.answerC: Alerts drivers to public recreation areas.
questions.answerD: Alerts drivers to upcoming food and gas locations.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs warn drivers of existing or potential driving hazards. You will usually see these signs in yellow or orange.

questions.question: You may continue carefully through an intersection with a yellow light if:
questions.answerA: There is an emergency vehicle crossing your lane.
questions.answerC: You are turning right.
questions.answerD: You are already within the intersection when the light changes to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a steady yellow light appears when you are already within an intersection, you should continue through the intersection carefully.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.answerD: About road construction.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: The top type of vehicular crash involving 16-year-old drivers in Pennsylvania is:
questions.answerA: Single vehicle/run-off-the-road.
questions.answerC: Driving in reverse on a side street.
questions.answerD: Driving on the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: The most frequent crash type in which 16-year-old drivers in Pennsylvania are involved is a single-vehicle, run-off-the-road crash. From 2009 to 2011, there were 2,293 crashes and 45 people killed.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerA: Either side
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.answerD: The left side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: When you want to make a right turn, your car must be:
questions.answerA: Near the center of the street.
questions.answerB: Close to the left side of the street.
questions.answerC: Close to the right side of the street.
questions.answerD: Past the center of the intersection when you begin to turn.
questions.explanation: As you prepare to make a right turn, you should get as far to the right side of the road as possible. Do not cut across lanes of traffic to perform any turn.

questions.question: When parking uphill on a hill or incline with a curb:
questions.answerA: Turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn your front wheels slightly to the right.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb.
questions.answerD: Keep your front wheels straight.
questions.explanation: To keep your vehicle from rolling into traffic when parked facing uphill, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. If you are parking uphill on a street that has no curb, turn the wheels sharply toward the edge of the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If you drive past these signs, you are going the wrong way and are at risk of a head-on collision. You should cautiously turn around.

questions.question: When changing lanes on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal a lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview and outside mirrors.
questions.answerC: Check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Any time you want to change lanes, you should properly signal your intentions well in advance, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot. You can check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means that you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with care.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed when a green light appears.
questions.answerD: Stop and proceed when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means "caution." If you approach such a light, slow down, look, and proceed with care.

questions.question: If you are unable to get a good view of cross traffic when stopped at an intersection controlled by a stop sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait five seconds, then proceed.
questions.answerC: Put down your windows, listen for traffic, and then proceed.
questions.answerD: Pull forward slowly, check for traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when clear.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a stop sign where you cannot see cross traffic, yield to any pedestrians and then carefully pull forward past the stop line until you can see clearly. Check for traffic and pedestrians. Go ahead when the intersection is clear.

questions.question: You need to use extra caution when driving near a pedestrian using a white cane because:
questions.answerA: He or she is deaf.
questions.answerB: He or she is a police officer.
questions.answerC: He or she is blind.
questions.answerD: He or she has poor balance.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.answerD: No turning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited. Do not make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: When passing a bicyclist, you should:
questions.answerA: Blast your horn to alert the bicyclist.
questions.answerB: Give them at least four feet of space.
questions.answerC: Remain on the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Put on your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: The law requires you to allow at least four feet of space between your vehicle and a bicyclist when passing them.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.answerD: May not turn right.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: When sharing the road with a truck, it is important to remember that trucks generally:
questions.answerA: Require longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerB: Require less time to pass on a downgrade than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerC: Require a smaller turning radius than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerD: Require less time to pass on an incline than smaller vehicles do.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, trucks need longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.

questions.question: As alcohol builds up in your blood, it:
questions.answerA: Slows down your reactions.
questions.answerC: Begins to metabolize itself more quickly.
questions.answerD: Decreases the number of driving errors.
questions.explanation: As alcohol builds up in your system, it will slow your reactions, make you feel more confident, and cause you to make more errors.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.answerD: Keep right on hills.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow line next to your lane means that passing is not permitted from your direction.

questions.question: It is best to keep a space cushion:
questions.answerA: Only in back of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the left and right sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only in front of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: On all sides of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you will have time to react to hazards on the roadway, it is best to keep a cushion of space on all sides of your vehicle. Do not crowd vehicles to your left and right sides.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.answerD: 0.1 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Have to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.answerD: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: One of the penalties for driving under the influence of alcohol is:
questions.answerA: A five-year driver license suspension.
questions.answerC: Required attendance at an Alcohol Highway Safety School.
questions.answerD: A 12-hour sentence in jail.
questions.explanation: In addition to other penalties, attending an Alcohol Highway Safety School will be required for first or second offenses at any level of impairment.

questions.question: Your ability to stop is affected by:
questions.answerA: Signal lights.
questions.answerC: The time of day.
questions.answerD: The condition of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to stop is greatly affected by the condition of the road. You need to reduce your speed when road conditions are poor in order to maintain control of your vehicle. You will be at risk if you are driving too quickly on roads that are slippery and you need to stop.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: No passing zone
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.answerD: Stop
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Right turn.
questions.answerC: Lane change.
questions.answerD: Road curve.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a T intersection is ahead.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: When driving through a work zone, it is a good safety practice to:
questions.answerA: Drive closely to the vehicle in front of you to keep traffic flowing freely.
questions.answerB: Shorten your usual following distance by about one-half.
questions.answerC: Turn on your cruise control.
questions.answerD: Double your usual following distance.
questions.explanation: The most common type of crash in work zones is the rear-end collision. To avoid this hazard, it is recommended that you double your following distance as you approach a work zone.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.answerD: Stop exactly where you are.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: Traffic fatalities in work zones are most commonly the result of:
questions.answerA: Tire blowouts.
questions.answerB: Hydroplaning due to water sprayed on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Loss of steering control after driving over wet paint.
questions.answerD: Carelessness and speeding.
questions.explanation: Carelessness and speeding are the main causes of traffic-related fatalities in work zones.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must turn left or right.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a T intersection.
questions.answerC: The road that you are on intersects with a divided highway.
questions.answerD: You are on an overpass above a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road that you are on intersects with a divided highway. A divided highway is two one-way roadways separated by a median or guide rail.

questions.question: An "End school zone" sign indicates:
questions.answerA: That the speed limit is 20 mph.
questions.answerB: The beginning of a reduced speed zone.
questions.answerC: The increased possibility of encountering pedestrians.
questions.answerD: The end of a reduced speed zone.
questions.explanation: Do not exceed the school zone speed limit during indicated times. The end of a reduced speed school zone will be indicated by an "End school zone" regulatory sign.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: The speed limit is ____ miles per hour when yellow lights are flashing on a school zone speed limit sign.
questions.explanation: When the flashing yellow lights on a school zone sign are activated, or during an indicated school zone time period, you may travel no faster than 15 mph.

questions.question: After a train has passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Check again for approaching trains and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Immediately proceed across the tracks.
questions.answerD: Blow your horn and proceed.
questions.explanation: Even at a railroad crossing with only one track, you should not immediately start across after a train has passed. Always check for other approaching trains before proceeding.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get some coffee.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.answerD: Turn on the radio.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.answerD: Easier on your eyes.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.answerD: Cars behind you.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Roads freeze quickly when they are:
questions.answerA: Flat.
questions.answerC: In the sun.
questions.answerD: Shaded.
questions.explanation: In cold or wet weather, you should take special care on sections of road that are shaded by trees or buildings. These areas freeze more quickly than the rest of the road and are the last parts of the road to dry.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerA: Upcoming intersections.
questions.answerC: An upcoming curve in the road.
questions.answerD: Changes in traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right.

questions.question: Allow a larger space cushion than usual when stopping:
questions.answerA: On an incline.
questions.answerC: At a stop sign.
questions.answerD: At a toll plaza.
questions.explanation: You should allow more space in front of your vehicle than usual when you are stopped on an uphill slope. If the vehicle in front of you rolls backward toward your vehicle when traffic begins to move again, it is less likely that there will be a collision.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection when the traffic light changes from green to solid yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Consider it the same as a caution sign and continue through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, unless you are too close to stop safely.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get through the intersection before the red light appears.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a solid yellow traffic light, slow to a stop before entering the intersection, if it is safe to do so. If you can't stop safely, drive carefully through the intersection.

questions.question: Before switching on the ignition, you should:
questions.answerA: Be sure only backseat passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerB: Be sure only adult passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerC: Be sure only child passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerD: Be sure all of the vehicle's occupants have buckled their seat belts.
questions.explanation: Develop a routine for entering and leaving your car. Before switching on the ignition, buckle your safety belt and see that all passengers do likewise.

questions.question: If you need to slow down or stop when other drivers may not expect it, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly tap your brake pedal a few times first.
questions.answerC: Look over your shoulder for traffic in your blind spot.
questions.answerD: Get ready to blow your horn.
questions.explanation: If you are going to brake where other drivers may not expect it, quickly tap your brake pedal three or four times.

questions.question: The right edge of a road is marked by a ____ line.
questions.answerA: Broken white
questions.answerC: Solid white
questions.answerD: Broken yellow
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to mark the right edge of a road.

questions.question: If a police officer requires you to take a blood, breath, or urine test, you:
questions.answerA: May choose which test you prefer.
questions.answerC: May refuse if underage.
questions.answerD: Must take the test or your license will be suspended.
questions.explanation: If the police arrest you for driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs and you refuse to take one or more chemical tests of breath, blood, or urine, your driving privilege will be automatically suspended for one year. This suspension will remain in place even if you are found not guilty of driving under the influence.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.answerD: Green, yellow, red.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: When no signs, signals, or police tell you what to do at an intersection, the law states:
questions.answerA: That drivers on the right must yield to drivers on the left.
questions.answerB: Nothing. There are no laws stating who must yield.
questions.answerC: That drivers going straight must yield to drivers turning left at the intersection.
questions.answerD: That drivers turning left must yield to drivers going straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: In the absence of signs, signals, or police instructions, drivers turning left at an intersection must yield to vehicles going straight.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: You want to turn left at an intersection. The light is green but oncoming traffic is heavy. You should:
questions.answerA: Use the next intersection.
questions.answerB: Wait at the crosswalk for traffic to clear.
questions.answerC: Wait in the center of the intersection for traffic to clear.
questions.answerD: Take the right-of-way since you have a green light.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn where there is approaching traffic, you must wait for the approaching traffic to go through before you turn. You may enter the intersection to prepare for your left turn if the light is green and no other vehicle ahead of you plans to make a left turn.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is usually caused by:
questions.answerA: Excessive stops.
questions.answerC: Sudden turns.
questions.answerD: Excessive speed.
questions.explanation: Your tires become less effective at clearing water from the road as you increase your speed. If you drive too fast, they may lose their grip entirely, leaving the vehicle sliding on a film of water. This is known as "hydroplaning."

questions.question: Drivers entering a roundabout or traffic circle:
questions.answerA: Must always stop before entering.
questions.answerB: Must yield to drivers already in the roundabout or traffic circle.
questions.answerC: Have the right-of-way if there is one lane.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way if there are two lanes.
questions.explanation: Drivers entering a roundabout or traffic circle must yield the right-of-way to drivers already in the circle.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerA: CD player
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.answerD: All of the above
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle if the line dividing your lane from the lane you wish to enter is a ____ line.
questions.answerA: Broken white
questions.answerC: Solid yellow
questions.answerD: Solid white
questions.explanation: White lines separate traffic lanes traveling in the same direction. You may cross broken white lines to pass, as long as the passing lane is clear.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerA: A designated no passing zone
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: “Highway hypnosis” is a driving condition that can result from:
questions.answerA: Staring at the roadway for long periods of time.
questions.answerC: Too much sleep the night before your trip.
questions.answerD: Short trips on expressways.
questions.explanation: "Highway hypnosis” happens when you stare straight ahead at the roadway for long periods of time and stop actively scanning ahead, behind, and around your vehicle. This can lead you to zone out, making you very likely to crash into traffic slowing or stopping ahead of you.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerA: Turn off all your lights.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: To pass a slower-moving vehicle on a two-lane, two-way road, you must:
questions.answerA: Not cross the centerline.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Use the lane that belongs to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: Passing on a two-lane, two-way road requires good judgment because you must use the lane belonging to oncoming traffic to complete your pass. Only pass if you may safely and legally do so.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal means that a ____ light will soon appear.
questions.answerA: Flashing yellow
questions.answerC: Steady red
questions.answerD: Flashing red
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light on a traffic signal indicates that a steady red light will soon appear.

questions.question: When a school bus has its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop at least 10 feet away from the bus.
questions.answerB: Pass if children have exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Stop if the bus is on the opposite side of a barrier.
questions.answerD: Drive slowly past the bus.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is flashing its red lights and has its stop arm extended, you are required to stop at least 10 feet away from the bus, unless the bus is stopped on the opposite side of a divided highway.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible.
questions.answerB: Not move your vehicle under any circumstances.
questions.answerC: Wait until the police arrive before moving your vehicle.
questions.answerD: None of the above.
questions.explanation: After a minor collision, move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible. Do not leave the scene of an accident without identifying yourself and rendering assistance.

questions.question: People under 16 years of age who use a false identification card to buy alcohol will:
questions.answerA: Receive a driving suspension that starts on their 16th birthday.
questions.answerB: Not be able to take the driver’s exam until their 21st birthday.
questions.answerC: Receive a driving suspension that starts on their 21st birthday.
questions.answerD: Be sent to an alcohol safety education class.
questions.explanation: Even if you are not driving, your driving privilege will be suspended if you are under 21 years of age and are convicted of possessing alcohol, lying about your age to obtain alcohol, or carrying a false ID card. If you are under 16 years of age, your suspension will not begin until your 16th birthday.

questions.question: When a truck driver behind you wants to pass your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Your speed should remain steady or decrease.
questions.answerC: You should change lanes.
questions.answerD: Your speed should increase.
questions.explanation: When a truck passes your vehicle, you will make it easier and safer for the truck driver if you reduce your speed slightly and then keep your reduced speed steady. In any event, do not increase your speed while the truck is passing you.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down. If possible, change lanes so you will not drive next to the stopped emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and continue to drive at the same speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to quickly pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space. If there is only one lane moving in your direction, or if changing lanes would be unsafe, you must slow down to a speed below the posted speed limit and give the stationary vehicle as much room as possible. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: When traveling more slowly than 40 miles per hour on a limited-access highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn to warn others.
questions.answerD: Use your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive below 40 mph on a limited-access highway, you should use your hazard (four-way) flashers to warn the drivers behind you.

questions.question: When making a turn, you must ____ your speed.
questions.answerA: Increase
questions.answerC: Vary
questions.answerD: Reduce
questions.explanation: When turning, you should reduce to a speed that allows you to maintain control of your vehicle, stay in your lane, and react to unexpected situations.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Parking spaces are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.
questions.answerC: Traffic in the lane must turn in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerD: Lanes are reserved for buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers.
questions.explanation: This sign marks parking spaces that are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.answerD: When making turns.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerA: Larger blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: If a traffic light at an intersection is broken or not functioning, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for it to be repaired.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait for a police officer to arrive.
questions.answerC: Continue as if the intersection is a four-way stop.
questions.answerD: Continue as you normally would.
questions.explanation: An intersection with a non-functioning traffic signal should be treated as a four-way stop.

questions.question: When driving on wet roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Drive slightly faster than the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed by five to ten miles per hour.
questions.answerD: Stay close to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: When roads become slippery, you should reduce your speed by five to ten miles per hour.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerD: Block the passing lane.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians ahead.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.answerD: Flagger ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: If a driver sees an animal on the roadway:
questions.answerA: No special action is required.
questions.answerB: The driver should honk their horn.
questions.answerC: The driver should pass the animal as closely as possible.
questions.answerD: The driver should be very cautious.
questions.explanation: Be very cautious any time you encounter an animal on the roadway. Pass the animal slowly to avoid startling or frightening it.
